title: Salesforce, Snowflake, Zscaler, Box: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today; Salesforce offered a muted sales outlook; Zscaler lifted its revenue forecasts
text:
* Apple shares were up 1.7% ahead of the bell, pointing to another strong day after it managed to close up more than 3% on Tuesday, shrugging off the broad markets declines.

* Zscaler jumped 6.9% premarket after the information security firm raised its revenue outlook for the year.

* As they have in recent days, Covid-19 vaccine makers are moving in the opposite direction of market sentiment. Moderna slipped 3.5%, Novavax shed 1.5% and Pfizer edged down 0.2%.

* Merck shares gained 2%. An outside panel of scientific advisers to the FDA narrowly recommended the agency authorize the experimental Covid-19 oral antiviral from Merck and partner Ridgeback Biotherapeutics.

* Vertex Pharmaceuticals climbed 6%. The biotechnology company said it had positive results in a phase 2 study of a treatment for kidney disease.

* GlobalFoundries rose 2.3% premarket. The contract chip maker swung to a third-quarter profit and its revenue rose 56%, driven by strong demand amid a chip shortage.

* Hewlett Packard Enterprise ticked down 1.1% premarket. The IT provider reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings and sales in line with Wall Street estimates.

* Box jumped 9.7%. The cloud-computing company's third-quarter results beat expectations and it raised full-year revenue guidance.

* Crude prices are up, and producers' stocks are up along with them. Occidental Petroleum gained 3.6%, Diamondback Energy added 3.3% and Devon Energy rose 3.1%.

* Travel stocks were also benefiting from the risk-on mood. Cruise operator Carnival rose 3.1%, hotel chain Hilton Worldwide gained 2.4% and Delta Air Lines climbed 2%. Casinos were up too with Las Vegas Sands adding 2.2% and Wynn Resorts up 1.1%.

* Snowflake, Splunk, Okta and Five Below are among the companies reporting earnings on Wednesday.

Chart of the Day

* Close to 27% of U.S. consumers said in October that they had applied for a credit card in the past 12 months, the highest level since 2019.

Write to James Willhite at james.willhite@wsj.com
